overview: Apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) if you have a disability or mental health condition that affects your ability to study - who qualifies and how much you can get
title: Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs)

table.body:
You can apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) if you have a disability or mental health condition or specific learning difficulty that affects your ability to study. 

You need to be a higher education student living in England.

DSAs are paid on top of student finance and you don't have to pay them back. The amount you get depends on your individual needs and not on income.

*[DSAs]: Disabled Students' Allowances
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The amount of Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) you can get depends on your individual needs - not your household income. 

You can get help with the costs of:

- specialist equipment like computer software
- non-medical helpers, such as a note-taker or reader
- extra travel costs you have to pay because of your disability
- other costs such as photocopying 

##Maximum amounts

The figures below are the maximum you can get - most students get less than this. 

Type of student | Specialist equipment allowance  | Non-medical helper allowance | General allowance
- | -
full-time  | up to £5,161 for the whole course | up to £20,520 a year | up to £1,724 a year
part-time | up to £5,161 for the whole course	 | up to £15,390 a year | up to £1,293 a year

If you're a part-time student the 'intensity' of your course may affect how much DSA you get. Intensity means how long your course takes to complete each year compared to an equivalent full-time course. Your course must:

- last at least a year
- not last more than 4 times as long as the equivalent full-time course 

If you start a course **before** 1 September 2012 your course must not last more than twice as long as the equivalent full-time course. 

You can also claim for extra travel costs you have to pay because of your disability - for example if you have to use taxis because you're unable to use public transport. 

Postgraduate students can get a single allowance of up to £10,260.

##How DSAs are paid

Money is paid directly to who provides the service or equipment or into your bank account.

*[DSA]: Disabled Students' Allowance

table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
You can apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) if you have a: 

- disability or long-term health condition
- mental health condition 
- specific learning difficulty like dyslexia or dyspraxia

You must also:

- have a condition that affects your ability to study 
- qualify for student finance from Student Finance England
- be studying on a course that lasts at least a year 

Part-time courses must:

- not last more than 4 times as long as the equivalent full-time course
- be at least 25% of the 'intensity' of the equivalent full-time course each year (for example, if your course takes 6 years to complete but would take 3 years full-time, it has an intensity of 50%)

^You can’t get DSAs if you qualify for equivalent help from elsewhere, like an NHS bursary^

##Proving you're eligible

You won’t automatically get DSAs - you need to send [proof of your eligibility](/disabled-students-allowances-dsas/further-information "proof of your eligibility") like a letter from your doctor or specialist. 

You will also need to have a needs assessment to decide what help you need. You'll then get a report listing equipment and other support you can get for your course.

*[DSAs]: Disabled Students' Allowances
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
To apply for Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) you need to fill in an application form and send it to Student Finance England. 

$A
Student Finance England
PO Box 210
Darlington
DL1 9HJ
$A

If you’ve applied for student finance you need to complete the short version of the form. If you’re only applying for DSAs complete the full version of the form. 

You can also claim extra travel costs you've had to pay because of your condition. 

##If you've applied for student finance - short form
$D  [Download DSA1 short application form (PDF, 180KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@educ/documents/digitalasset/dg_200348.pdf "DSA1 short application form") $D
##If you're only applying for DSAs - full form
$D [Download DSA1 full application form (PDF, 276KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@educ/documents/digitalasset/dg_200346.pdf "DSA1 full application form")$D

##Claim travel and other expenses

$D[Download Expenses claim form 2011/12 (PDF, 88KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@educ/documents/digitalasset/dg_199621.pdf "Expenses claim form 2011/12") $D

The DSA expenses claim form for 2012/13 will be available in October 2012.

table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##Proving your disability

Send medical evidence with your application – for example, a letter from your doctor or specialist.

If you have a specific learning difficulty such as dyslexia, you’ll need to provide a 'diagnostic assessment' from a psychologist or suitably qualified specialist teacher. If you had this done when you were under age 16, you may need to get reassessed. 

If you need a new diagnostic assessment but can’t afford to pay for it, you may be able to get financial help through the [Access to Learning Fund](/access-to-learning-fund "Access to Learning Fund").

##Your ‘needs assessment’ 

Student Finance England will ask you to have a 'needs assessment' test to work out what help you need. 

You shouldn't book a needs assessment until Student Finance England ask you to. 

The assessment is paid for through any Disabled Students' Allowances (DSAs) entitlement you may have.

##Help and advice 

Find out more about how much you can get, if you qualify and how to apply in the ‘Bridging the gap’ guide.

$D
[Download Bridging the Gap, a guide to Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs) 2012/13 (PDF, 411KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@educ/documents/digitalasset/dg_200484.pdf "Bridging the Gap, a guide to Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs) 2012/13")
$D

If you need advice about financial help, contact the disability adviser at your university or college or speak to Student Finance England.

$C

**Student Finance England**

**Telephone:** 0845 300 5090

**Minicom:** 0845 604 4434

**Opening hours:** Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm; Saturday and Sunday, 9am to 5:30pm

$C

##If your circumstances change

If your circumstances change, contact Student Finance England. 

For example:
 
- if your condition gets worse you may be able to get extra help 
- if you change your course you may still get DSAs but you won’t get any extra equipment allowance

##Appeals

If your application is turned down you can ask for an explanation or for Student Finance England to review your case. Contact Student Finance England for more details.
